stream_context.summary: Kaze, fresh off releasing the second public demo (Course 1), works on Course 15 – a retro-futuristic 1960s “space colony” level. The session centres on level layout, bouncy monorail platforms, and an as-yet-unfinalised boss concept while also addressing hardware and performance issues after the demo launch.

development_findings.summary: The second public demo (containing only Course 1) was released today; a full play-through video is scheduled for tomorrow.
development_findings.quote: I released the second demo today… I’m gonna upload a full playthrough of it tomorrow.

development_findings.summary: Course 15 has been completely redesigned from its earlier ‘slide’ version into a retro-futuristic space colony featuring satellites, monorails and a rocket.
development_findings.quote: This level has changed a lot since stream last saw it. It’s extremely different now… the theme for this is like retrofuturism, so we want this to look like a space colony as imagined in 1960.

development_findings.summary: Boss concept is in flux: started as a gelatinous ‘Blob’ with a kickable brain, shifted to Yoshi’s Island’s Sluggy the Unshaven, and is now leaning toward a giant space squid emerging from bright rifts that attack with tentacles and laser eyes.
development_findings.quote: Alright, fuck it. Instead of the blob, it’s Sluggy the Unshaven… Actually a big squid can work.

development_findings.summary: Planned boss mechanics include dynamic lights to telegraph rift locations, tentacle attacks from multiple directions and damaging the squid by striking its exposed eyes.
development_findings.quote: We could use dynamic lights to shine light onto Mario so the player knows where the attack is coming from… then the eyes are red pulsating and you kick the eyes.

development_findings.summary: Spin / ground-pound-dive (Z + A) has been nerfed: it now clears momentum and is meant as a ‘shame’ safety move rather than a traversal exploit.
development_findings.quote: I’m gonna remove all momentum because it’s supposed to be like a safety move… you’re not supposed to be using it all over the place.

development_findings.summary: Monorail network design: outer circle ~4 rails, middle ~3, bottom ~8; players can climb them and some rails may have trampoline sections.
development_findings.quote: It would be probably like 4 in this circle and then 3 in this circle, and maybe like 8 in the bottom circle.

development_findings.summary: Experimenting with various trampoline visuals (speaker-style pads, hexagons) and bounce strengths while trying to telegraph behaviour clearly.
development_findings.quote: Maybe this was a bad idea… you would think these like carry you, but then they do that.

development_findings.summary: Optimization attempt: executing code directly from cartridge saved ~2 ms CPU but gave no RDP gain, so the approach was abandoned.
development_findings.quote: My idea was we run the code directly from the cartridge… Unfortunately it did not and I don’t know why.

development_findings.summary: EverDrive X7 boot crash traced to uncleared memory; Kaze is testing a build that invalidates all RAM at startup.
development_findings.quote: I found out today that my game does not boot on the EverDrive X7… I’m trying a build where I invalidate the entire RAM before I boot the game.

development_findings.summary: Recent performance gains are being spent on higher polygon counts and visual detail in new areas.
development_findings.quote: Speed gains are mostly spent on like more polygons and details, for example this area here… we need the performance gains here.

development_findings.summary: Kaze rejects traditional colour theory, selecting colours by intuition.
development_findings.quote: I don’t like colour theory. I don’t think colour theory is real.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is openly sceptical of traditional colour theory, calling it ‘bullshit’.
context_findings.quote: I don’t even use colour theory.

context_findings.summary: He dislikes the social ritual of asking ‘How are you?’ and debates the issue through Immanuel Kant’s ethics.
context_findings.quote: I hate when people ask how are you. It’s the worst.

context_findings.summary: Surprised and pleased by the community’s eagerness to play the demo.
context_findings.quote: I’m surprised how many people wanted to play the demo.

context_findings.summary: Feels distracted by chat and cuts the stream short to focus on post-demo tasks and fixing video inaccuracies.
context_findings.quote: Either way, today I think I’m keeping the stream short… I want to make sure the demo release and video goes fine.

context_findings.summary: Mentions he does not drink coffee, saying it ‘tastes like ass’.
context_findings.quote: I don’t drink coffee. I think coffee tastes like ass.

biobak.summary: Expected to supply improved textures for the trampoline/monorail platform concept.
biobak.quote: I’m sure Biobak can find a better texture for what I’m trying to convey.

biobak.summary: Engages Kaze in a discussion about Kant’s philosophy, challenging his interpretation.

key_stories.title: Demo Day Surprise
key_stories.summary: Kaze quietly drops the second public demo (Course 1). Community uptake is higher than expected.
key_stories.challenge: Release a stable, enticing demo while juggling ongoing development.
key_stories.process: Polished Course 1, packaged the ROM, published download and prepared a playthrough video.
key_stories.outcome: Positive early feedback; Kaze plans more promotional content.
key_stories.key_quote: Looks like people somewhat like it.

key_stories.title: Space Colony Boss Pivot
key_stories.summary: Brainstorming takes the Course 15 boss from ‘Blob’ to ‘Sluggy’ to a tentacled space squid.
key_stories.challenge: Find a boss that fits the retro-futuristic setting and offers clear, fun mechanics.
key_stories.process: Live ideation with chat, debating aesthetics and readability, drafting attack patterns and damage phases.
key_stories.outcome: Tentative decision on a squid with rift-based tentacles and laser eyes, but final design still pending.
key_stories.key_quote: A big squid can work… imagine black holes with tentacles coming out of it all over the level attacking Mario.

key_stories.title: Cartridge Code Experiment
key_stories.summary: Kaze tests running code directly from the N64 cartridge to free RAM bandwidth.
key_stories.challenge: Reduce RDP bottlenecks and improve frame rate.
key_stories.process: Built experimental ROM, measured CPU and RDP times.
key_stories.outcome: 2 ms CPU savings but no RDP benefit; approach shelved.
key_stories.key_quote: Unfortunately it did not and I don’t know why.

open_questions.context: Stream ended with multiple competing ideas (Blob, Sluggy, space squid) and no clear choice.
questions: Which boss design have you ultimately chosen and why?
How will the fight balance readability, challenge and technical constraints?
What role will Zeina’s animation play in bringing the creature to life?

open_questions.context: Several visual and mechanical prototypes were shown, none final.
questions: What visual cues will signal that a monorail segment is bouncy?
How will bounce strength and trajectory be taught to the player?
What textures or models is Biobak preparing for these platforms?

open_questions.context: Kaze rejects formal colour theory but still needs cohesive art.
questions: How do you and Biobak collaborate on palettes without relying on colour theory?
Can you outline the practical criteria you use when approving colours?

open_questions.context: Cartridge-execution test failed to improve RDP; other strategies unmentioned.
questions: What alternative optimisation techniques are next on the list?
Are you considering display-list restructuring or parallel RSP tasks?

open_questions.context: Only Course 1 is public; timeline for further demos or full release unclear.
questions: What milestones will trigger the next public demo?
Do you have a target window for the full hack’s release?
